skill.name: file-organizer
skill.description: Intelligently organizes your files and folders across your computer by understanding context, finding duplicates, suggesting better structures, and automating cleanup tasks. Reduces cognitive load and keeps your digital workspace tidy without manual effort.
skill.summary: Personal organization assistant for maintaining clean, logical file structures
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: This skill is a documentation-only resource providing instructions for file organization tasks. Static analysis flagged 71 patterns (md5 usage, shell commands), but all are false positives - they are instructional examples in markdown code blocks, not executable code. The skill teaches users to run standard file system commands like find, mv, and mkdir. No malicious intent detected.

low_findings.title: Documentation contains shell command examples
low_findings.description: The SKILL.md file contains numerous examples of bash commands (find, mv, mkdir, ls, du) for file organization. These are instructional examples in markdown code blocks, not executable code. Users must manually run these commands. This is standard practice for CLI tool documentation and presents minimal risk.

content.user_title: Organize files and clean up messy directories
content.value_statement: Managing files manually across folders is time consuming and mentally exhausting. File Organizer helps you maintain clean, logical folder structures by analyzing your files, finding duplicates, and automating organization tasks with Claude Code.
actual_capabilities: Analyze folder structures and identify organization issues
Find duplicate files using checksums and file metadata
Propose logical folder hierarchies based on file types and purposes
Generate bash commands to move, rename, and organize files systematically
Create organization plans with before and after structures
Provide maintenance tips and commands for ongoing file management
limitations: Does not execute commands automatically - requires user approval and manual execution
Cannot recover deleted files or undo file operations without backups
File analysis limited to metadata and filenames, not deep content analysis
Duplicate detection uses checksums which may not catch similar but non-identical files

use_cases.title: Clean up messy Downloads folder
use_cases.description: Sort hundreds of accumulated downloads into organized folders by file type, purpose, and date. Archive old files and identify duplicates taking up space.
use_cases.target_user: Anyone with an overflowing Downloads directory

use_cases.title: Organize project directories
use_cases.description: Restructure project folders to separate active work from archived projects. Establish consistent naming conventions and folder hierarchies for better navigation.
use_cases.target_user: Developers and project managers with multiple ongoing projects

use_cases.title: Find and remove duplicate files
use_cases.description: Scan directories for duplicate files using checksums. Review duplicates with metadata to decide which copies to keep and which to delete for storage savings.
use_cases.target_user: Users managing large photo libraries or document collections

prompt_templates.title: Organize Downloads folder
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me organize my Downloads folder by moving documents, images, and installers into appropriate directories

prompt_templates.title: Find duplicate files
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all duplicate files in my Documents folder and show me which ones I should keep based on date and location
prompt_templates.scenario: Identify and remove redundant file copies

prompt_templates.title: Restructure project directory
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my Projects folder structure and suggest improvements to separate active projects from archived ones with consistent naming

prompt_templates.title: Comprehensive workspace cleanup
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze my home directory and create a comprehensive organization plan separating work files, personal files, and archives with maintenance commands

output_examples.input: Find duplicate files in my Documents folder
output_examples.output: Found 12 sets of duplicates totaling 89 MB. Set 1: proposal.pdf appears in 3 locations - Documents (modified Mar 15), Desktop (modified Mar 10), and old folder (modified Mar 15). Recommendation: Keep Documents version as most recent in correct location. Delete other 2 copies to save 4.6 MB.

Analyzed 347 files in Downloads. Proposed structure: Work (83 PDFs and docs), Personal (45 images), Installers (12 DMG files), Archive (207 files older than 3 months). Ready to create 4 folders and move files with your approval.

Current structure has 23 projects with inconsistent naming and mixed active and archived work. Proposed: Create Active and Archive folders, move 9 projects untouched since 2022 to Archive organized by year, rename remaining projects to client-name-project-name format, consolidate 3 duplicate project folders.

best_practices: Start with small, low-risk folders like Downloads before organizing critical directories to build confidence in the process
Always review and approve the organization plan before executing file moves, and maintain backups for important data
Establish regular maintenance schedules - weekly for Downloads, monthly for project reviews, quarterly for duplicate scans
anti_patterns: Do not organize active project directories without understanding their current structure and dependencies first
Avoid deleting files without reviewing duplicates carefully - dates and locations matter for determining which copy to keep
Do not apply aggressive cleanup rules to directories you access infrequently - you may not remember what files are important

faq.question: Will this skill automatically move or delete my files?
faq.answer: No. This skill generates organization plans and bash commands, but you must review and manually execute them. Nothing happens without your explicit approval.

faq.question: How does duplicate file detection work?
faq.answer: The skill uses file checksums like md5 to identify exact duplicate files, along with size and name comparisons. It shows you all copies with their locations and modification dates so you can decide which to keep.

faq.question: Can I undo file organization changes?
faq.answer: The skill logs all move operations, but you should maintain your own backups. Consider testing organization plans on a copy of your files first, or use version control for important directories.

faq.question: What file types can this skill organize?
faq.answer: This skill works with all file types. It organizes files based on extensions, metadata, names, dates, and sizes. Common categories include documents, images, videos, archives, code projects, and spreadsheets.

faq.question: How should I maintain organization after the initial cleanup?
faq.answer: Run weekly cleanups on high-traffic folders like Downloads, monthly reviews of active projects, and quarterly duplicate scans. The skill provides maintenance commands customized to your folder structure.

faq.question: Is it safe to use on my entire home directory?
faq.answer: Start with smaller, less critical folders first. For home directory organization, the skill will ask clarifying questions about which areas to focus on and what to avoid, like active projects or system folders.
